María has been receiving loans from her community bank for two loan cycles, and has used them to increase her production of chickens, as she works breeding and selling these birds. She sells them by walking around the community, in stores, or to her neighbors. She also has a cow and 2 calves.

She is strong woman, and a happy one. She is 63 years old, in a civil marriage, and the mother of 7 children, of which 6 are married and one lives independently. Only her 26 year old daughter is single - she works making pants and contributes to the household expenses. Her husband is not in work because he is ill. The house they live in is fairly old and they have lived in if for some time, but they are content because it is their property.

With the new loan that the Fundacion Espoir grants her, she will buy more chickens, plus food and vitamins to make them grow. Her big dream is to be successful in her business.

Translated from Spanish by Alison Hynd, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy chickens, plus food and vitamins for them

loans.name: Clemencia Beneranda

texts.es:
la señora  Clemencia P. es  socia del banco comunal Siempre Amigas, vive en la comunidad La Gloria en la parroquia el Valle  siendo su nombre completo  San Bautista de el Valle se encuentra al sureste de Cuenca teniendo como atractivo su laguna de Cochapamba llena de totoras, su edad es de 44 años, se encuentra casada y tiene 3 hijos de 16, 14, 11 años de edad, su hijo de 16 años estudia en el colegio Guillermo Mensi, su hija de 14 en el colegio Manuela Garaicoa de Calderón, el  de 11 en la escuela Tomás Rendón, su esposo es carpintero y posee su taller  en su propia casa.

María es sastre trabajó en esta actividad muchos años para otras personas hasta que decidió  independizarse y ahora tiene 14 años en su propio negocio y nos comenta que el trabajo ha bajado un poco, elabora todo tipo de ropa de hombre y mujer.

Se encuentra en su tercer ciclo en la fundación gracais a la señora Luz Yunga  otra socia del banco comunal que la invito a formar parte de este grupo de mujeres carismáticas y alegres, con el nuevo crédito que reciba comprará  una máquina de coser para su negocio, siendo su gran sueño llegar a tener su propio taller y más grande ya que al momento trabaja en casa.
texts.en:
Señora Clemencia P. is a member of the communal bank Friends Forever. She lives in La Gloria, in the El Valle parish (full name San Bautista de el Valle) to the southeast of Cuenca, famous for Lake Cochapamba, full of reeds. She is 44, married, with 3 children ages 16, 14, and 11. Her 16-year-old son is in Guillermo Mensi school, her 14-year-old daughter in Manuela Garaicoa de Calderón school, and the 11-year-old in Tomás Rendón school. Her husband is a carpenter with a shop in his own home. María is a tailor, having worked for other people in this trade for many years, she decided to go out on her own and now she has had her own business for 14 years. She tells us that work has gone down a little. She sews all types of men's and women's clothing. This is her third loan through this foundation, thanks to Señora Luz Yunga, another member of the communal bank who invited her to join this group of happy and charismatic women. With this new loan, she will buy a sewing machine for her business, her dream being to have her own larger shop, since for the present she works at home.

Translated from Spanish by Susan Sanford, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of sewing machine

loans.name: Jose Romulo

texts.es:
El señor José P. es el único socio varón del banco Comunal Siempre Amigas, vive a las afueras de la ciudad de Cuenca en la comunidad San Pedro parroquia El Valle, esta parroquia se caracteriza por alta producción de maíz, papas, etc., teniendo como atractivos turísticos,  la colina de Tasqui la cual nos regala una hermosa vista de la parroquia y de la ciudad de Cuenca.

José es sastre de profesión  para el cual estudio un año en el Gremio de  Artesanos para obtener su titulo profesional, pero desde sus 14 años trabajaba junto a sus hermanos que le enseñaron éste arte,  posee un pequeño taller en su casa y no tiene horario fijo para trabajar ya que es su propio jefe.

Este es su segundo crédito en la fundación y fue su hermana quien lo incentivó para formar parte de este grupo, tiene 26 años de edad,  casado y es padre de dos hijos, una niña  de 5 años  y un  bebe de 7 meses, su esposa es  costurera y trabaja en un almacén, no tiene casa propia y viven en casa desu suegra.

Con el nuevo crédito que la FUNDACION ESPOIR le otorgue  va a comprar techo Ardex para seguir en la construcción de  su casa propia que es uno de sus sueños y espera pronto verlo cristalizado.
texts.en:
Señor José P. is the only male member of the communal bank Friends Forever. He lives on the outskirts of Cuenca in the community of San Pedro, El Valle parish. This area is known for its high production of corn, potatoes, etc., with tourist attractions such as Tasqui hill that gives a beautiful view of the parish and the city of Cuenca. José is a tailor by profession. He studied one year in the Artisans Guild to get his professional credential, but he has worked with his brothers since the age of 14 learning this art. He has a small shop in his house and does not have a fixed work schedule since he is his own boss. This is his second loan through the foundation, it was his sister who encouraged him to join this group. He is 26, married, and the father of two children, a 5-year-old daughter and a baby of 7 months. His wife is a seamstress working in a shop, they do not have their own home, but are living in the home of his in-laws. With this new loan through FUNDACION ESPOIR, he will buy Ardex roofing to proceed with the construction of his own home, which is one of his dreams and which he hopes to see realized very soon.

Translated from Spanish by Susan Sanford, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of roofing material

loans.name: Gertrudiz Maribel

texts.es:
La señora Gertrudiz Maribel forma parte del Banco Comunal Aníbal San Andrés esta conformado por 19 prestataria las reuniones son en el Cantón Montecristi, este lugar es reconocido por su artesanía y por sus atractivos turísticos como sus hermosas playas en el provincia de Manabí.

Gertrudiz Maribel comparte el negocio con su esposo ellos se dedican a la compra y venta de pescado, lo compran en la playa de Manta a la madrugada que llegan los pescadores al puerto en sus lanchas, adquieren el pescado por gavetas ya fileteado listo para preparase o para ser enviado a Quito al mercado San Roque o al mercado Mayorista donde tienen sus clientes fijos, otra parte del pescado lo vende en su casa a su vecinos del sector.

Nuestra socia con este nuevo préstamo comprará gavetas  y más pescado para abstecer a sus clientes siempre e incrementar su negocio y buscar nuevos clientes, así como para aumentar sus ganacias
texts.en:
Mrs Gertrudiz Maribel is a member of the communal bank Anibal San Andrés. The meetings have 19 lending groups in the Montecristi Canton, a place known for its handicrafts and for its tourist attractions, such as the beautiful beaches in the Manabí province. Gertrudiz Maribel has the business with her husband. Together they work buying and selling fish They buy the fish on the Manta beach at dawn when the fishermen come in in their boats. They collect the filleted fish in containers and either have it ready to cook, or to send to Quito for the San Roque market or for the wholesale market. There they have their regular customers. They also sell the fish to their neighbors from their home. Our member will use the loan to buy containers, and more fish to be able to supply her customers all the time and to increase her business, and to look for new customers. This way she can have more profit.

Translated from Spanish by Miriam Palacio, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy containers and more fish

loans.name: Galo Raul

texts.es:
El señor Galo Raúl nos  brindo la oportunidad de conocer la forma en que el se dedica a trabajar, dice que gracias a la mama ingreso  a la Fundación y se siente muy bien trabajando con los créditos que recibe, ahora el forma parte del Banco Comunal Aníbal San Andrés en la ciudad de Montecristi en la provincia de Manabí.

El señor Galo se dedica al comercio de pescado desde hace 15 años, empezó  muy joven en el trabajo del papá el era quien lo acompañaba a trabajar y ahí aprendió el negocio, cuando cumplió la mayoría de edad el se independizó y emprendió su propio negocio, y desde entonces no ha dejado de trabajar, ahora que ya tiene su propia familia y comparte el oficio con sus hijos, el mayor que tiene 14 años de edad lo acompaña, su labor empieza desde las 4 de la mañana, todos los días tiene que viajar hasta la playa de Manta donde llegan las embarcaciones y comprar las gavetas, y  una vez hecho el negocio empieza el recorrido por los sectores rurales de Montecristi.

Don Galo de lunes a sábados se dedica a su trabajo, para poder movilizarse tiene que alquilar un triciclo. Con este nuevo crédito pagara a sus proveedores ya que el deja a credito su producto a sus clientes frecuentes y comprará mas pescado  para incrementar su negocio ya que están elevados los precios del pescado.

El sueño de Don Galo es poder comprarse una camioneta para trasladarse con su negocios a los sectores donde el recorre, eso le será de gran ayuda.
texts.en:
Mr. Galo Raúl brings us the opportunity to know the way in which he makes his living. He says it is thanks to his mother that he joined the Fundación and he feels good working with the loans that he receives. Currently, he is part of the Aníbal San Andrés communal bank in the city of Montecristi in the province of Manabí. For the past 15 years, Mr. Galo has worked in commercial fishing. He began young, working for his father. He accompanied him to work and, in this way, learned the business. When he came of age, he went independent and started his own business. Since then he has not stopped working. Now that he has his own family, he shares the trade with his children. The oldest is 14 years old and goes with him to work. The work starts at 4 in the morning. Every day he has to travel to Manta beach where the boats arrive and buys the fish. Once the negotiation is complete he begins the route through the rural areas of Montecristi. Mr. Galo works Monday through Saturday. For transportation, he rents a three-wheeled motorized vehicle. With this new loan he will pay his suppliers and buy more fish in order to grow his business now that they are increasing the price of fish. Mr. Galo’s dream is to be able to buy himself a small car in order to transport his business to the areas along his route. This would be a great help.

Translated from Spanish by Emma Felten, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To pay his suppliers and buy more fish

loans.name: Sergia Margarita

texts.es:
La señora Sergia  Margarita pertenece al Banco Comunal Everest Desde hace un año y medio porque la invito la mama y le dio buenas regencias de la Fundación, ella  es de profesión modista y realiza su trabajo en casa, tiene su pequeño taller, desde hace 17 años cose ropa para toda la comunidad, en tiempo de clase uniformes y además para toda ocasión, los hijos le ayudan en las tareas de la casa mientras ella se dedica a la costura, desde que era soltera aprendió la profesión el esposo también se dedica a otro trabajo para juntos salir adelante con sus hijos.

Con este nuevo préstamo la señora Sergia Margarita invertirá en maíz en esta época lo hacen desde hace algunos años, y para sembrar se  necesitan ureas, insecticida, fertilizante mano de obra y con el préstamo también podrá  pagar a los jornaleros.

Su sueño es poder comprarse una maquina profesional para que le facilite la costura, ya que con esta maquinas rusticas que tiene se le complica terminar las costuras, con la moderna tendría mayor demanda podría obtener mejores ganancias. Ella se dedica confeccionar entre semana porque el fin de semana tiene que  entregarlos y no le gusta quedar mal con sus clientes.
texts.en:
Señora Sergia Margarita has belonged to the communal bank, "Everest" for a year and a half. Her mother invited her to join and told her good things about Fundación Espoir. She works as a dressmaker in her home, where she has a small workshop. She has made clothing for all of the community for 17 years, including school uniforms and clothing for every occasion. Her children help her with the housework while she sews. She has done this work since she was single. Her husband has another job and together they work to take good care of their children. With this new loan, she will invest in corn, which she has been growing for several years. To grow it, she needs insecticide and fertilizer and labor, and she will also use the loan to pay for some day laborers. Her dream is to be able to buy a professional sewing machine to help her with her work, since she has an older machine that makes finishing her clothing difficult. With the modern machine, she would have higher demand and would be able to make more profit. She sews during the week, and on the weekends, she delivers her clothing, and she doesn't like to leave her customers unhappy.

Translated from Spanish by Tanya Harper, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase corn, insecticide, and fertilizer

loans.name: Flora Aracely

texts.es:
La señora Flora es socia del Banco Comunal Everes en la parroquia rural Pueblo Nuevo en la provincia de Manabí, este es un sector que se dedica a la agricultura y a la avicultura.

 Flora esta dedicada a la venta de productos de belleza,  ropa y zapatos que  lo maneja  bajo  pedidos, la ropa la compra en Portoviejo, comercializa productos Avon  hace 8 años y Yanbal  hace 2,  trabaja sola y  recorre las comunidades por el sector donde vive, tiene 4 hijos el esposo no trabaja y ella se ha visto en la necesidad de trabajar para sacar adelante a la familia, su mercderia deja a crédito y cada 8 días realiza los cobros. nuestra socia  invertirá todo el crédito en los productos como cremas, perfumes, tratamientos de belleza y mas cosmeticos así como pantalanes, blusas, camisas, bermudas etc porque  tiene varios pedidos de ropa por entregar a sus clientes, por el momento se siente bien con sus negocios pero no descarta la posibilidad de tener otro trabajo para ayudar mas a su familia cuenta que se le hace difícil porque han bajado las ventas.

La señora Flora vive con sus hijos y el esposo,  uno de sus anhelos es poder salir a trabajar a otro país.
texts.en:
Señora Flora is a member of the communal bank, "Everes" in the rural parish of Pueblo Nuevo in the province of Manabí, which is an area that is dedicated to agriculture and poultry farming. Flora sells beauty products, clothing, and shoes, which she does by taking orders. She buys the clothing in Portoviejo. She has sold Avon products for 8 years and Yanbal products for 2 years. She works alone and travels to communities in the area where she lives. She has 4 children. Her husband doesn't work, and she saw the need to work to take care of their family. She sells her merchandise on credit, and she collects payments every week. Our member will invest all of her loan in products like creams, perfumes, beauty treatments, and more cosmetics as well as pants, blouses, shirts, shorts, etc. She has various clothing orders to deliver to her customers. For the moment, she feels good with her business but she doesn't discard the possibility of having another job to help her family more because it is difficult because her sales have decreased. Flora lives with her children and her husband. One of her dreams is to be able to work in another country.

Translated from Spanish by Tanya Harper, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy creams, perfumes, beauty treatments, blouses, shirts, pants, and shorts

loans.name: Zoila Nieve

texts.es:
La señora Zoila es nuestra socia desde hace 4 ciclos, y pertenece al Banco Comunal Everes en la parroquia Pueblo Nuevo en la provincia de Manabí, este sector donde ser reúnen Nuetras prestamistas esta rodeado de una gran vegetación una tierra muy productiva.

La señora Zoila ingresó a la Fundación motivada por una amiga que le aconsejo para que siga trabajando con los préstamo de la Fundación y ya tiene 4 ciclos.Nuestra socia se dedica desde hace dos años a la cría de cerdos y pollos, en la casa acondicionó un espacio para ubicar su pequeña granja, nos comentó que es un lugar espacioso donde tiene varios galpones, la manera de trabajar es la siguiente, compra pequeños los pollos y los cerdos y se encarga de hacerlos crecer, cada 8 meses cría de 3 a 4 cerdos tienen que pasar 6  meses para que estén aptos para la venta, por el sector donde vive es fácil venderlos hay  personas que le hacen pedidos con anterioridad, por otra parte los pollos se toman 6 semanas para terminar el proceso de cría.

Para la señora Zoila este negocio familiar lo manejan muy bien y le gusta todo lo que hasta ahora ha conseguido con su esfuerzo, con este nuevo préstamo invertirá en más críasde pollos, crdos  y productos alimenticios para su crianza y una parte del crédito invertirá en el sembrío de plátanos y limones.
texts.en:
Señora Zoila has been a member through 4 loan periods, belonging to the communal bank Everes, Pueblo Nuevo parish, province of Manabí. This area where our members meet is surrounded with vegetation, it is a very productive area. Señora Zoila came to the foundation encouraged by a friend who counseled her to keep working with loans from the foundation, and now she has already been through 4 loan cycles. She has been raising pigs and chickens for two years, working in the following manner. She buys the young chickens and pigs and she herself undertakes the raising of the animals, fattening 3 or 4 pigs every 8 months. They have to be older than 6 months to be ready for sale, but it is easy to sell them in her area, people give her orders ahead of time. Chickens on the other hand take 6 weeks to be ready. Señora Zoila handles this family business very well, and she has been pleased with everything she has been able to do up to now. With this new loan she will purchase more breeder chickens, pigs, and foods to feed them. One part of the loan will be invested in planting bananas and lemons.

Translated from Spanish by Susan Sanford, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of livestock

loans.name: Neyda Lucia

texts.es:
En el banco Comunal Everes se reúne en la parroquia Pueblo Nuevo en la provincia de Manabí donde podemos disfrutar de las mas hermosas playas del Ecuador.

Neyda esta soltera tiene 22 años es una de las socias mas jovenes de su banco comunal,  el   crédito solicitado  lo invertirá en sabanas ya que ella  tiene dos años con este negocio, los días domingos se dedica a recorrer su comunidad  y la mama en  casa le ayuda en las ventas, ella esta radicada en Portoviejo porque trabaja en un local de comida rápida, cuando le preguntamos si este negocio es rentable nos comentó que si.

Neyda por medio de una familia que tiene en Cuenca  empezó a vender las sabanas abasteciendo directo de la fabrica donde  compra al costo, cada juego de estas sabanas están por los 35 dólares, aparte de vender por su sector  vende a sus compañeros de trabajo, y deja a crédito dependiendo del monto hasta tres pagos.

Con el  préstamo que rciba comprará más sábanas para tener un stock suficiente para sus clientes, para ir formando un capital porque su deseo es estudiar hosteleria y turismo que por cuestión de tiempo no ha colcuir  sus estudios que esta segura de lograrlo.
texts.en:
The members of the communal bank, "Everes," meet in the parish of Pueblos Nuevo in the province of Manabí, where we enjoy Ecuador's most beautiful beaches. Neyda, who is single and 22, is one of the youngest members of the communal bank. She will invest the loan she is requesting in sheets. She has had this business for 2 years. On Sundays, she travels through her community, and her mom stays home to help her with her sales. She lives in Portoviejo because she works at a fast food restaurant. When we asked her if this business was profitable, she said yes. Neyda started selling sheets because of a family member she has that works in Cuenca. She can get her supply of sheets directly from the factory and buys them at cost. Each set of these sheets costs $35. Besides selling in her area, she also sells to her coworkers. She sells on credit depending on the amount up to three payments. With this loan, she will buy more sheets to have a sufficient stock for her customers so she can save up some capital because her dream is to study hotel management and tourism. Because of time, she hasn't been able to finish her studies, but she is certain that she will.

Translated from Spanish by Tanya Harper, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase sheets to supply her business

loans.name: Isabelita

texts.en:
Isabelita comes from Antipolo, Rizal province, in the Philippines. She is a 51-year-old woman, is married, and is the mother of three children. All of her children are finished degree holders. 

Isabelita operates a passenger jeepney (a small bus) and tends a home for rent at the same time. She started these businesses only when ASHI gave her an opportunity to obtain a loan. The businesses are a big help for the family in covering their expenses and to set aside savings for the future.

The couple is requesting a loan of PHP 20,000 to pay for a general overhaul of the jeepney, permit, and other spare parts for the jeepney. The proceeds of her business give her money to support the immediate and basic needs of her family. 

Isabelita hopes that her business will become successful someday. She still dreams of having a durable and concrete house of her own and to save for her family’s future.

Isabelita wants to thank ASHI and Kiva lenders who are sponsoring this loan. That is one of the greatest opportunities for her to start reaching for her goals.

About ASHI: Ahon sa Hirap Inc. (ASHI) has the distinction of being the oldest existing replication of Grameen Bank Approach (GBA) to credit delivery to the bottom poor in the Philippines. With its outstanding achievements over the years, it has become one of the role models in credit delivery to the poor in the country.

loans.use: To pay for a general overhaul of jeepney, permit, and other spare parts for the jeepney.

loans.name: Madeline's Group

texts.en:
Madeline U. is from the town of Benito Soliven. She is 42 years old. Madeline is the leader of a 14-member loan group sponsored by ASKI. Although each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are collectively responsible for repaying the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Madeline U..

Madeline is married and has 4 school-aged children. To make a living, Madeline sells rice in the local community. Madeline has been engaged in her business for over 6 years and earns approximately 18,000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2009, Madeline joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Madeline has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 PHP from ASKI. Madeline is requesting a new loan of 12000 PHP to purchase additional products to sell. This will be Madeline's third loan from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay for her children's tuition. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Alma's Group

texts.en:
Alma M. is from the village of Sampaguita in Solana, Cagayan. She is 40 years old. Alma is the leader of a 6-member loan group sponsored by ASKI. Although each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are collectively responsible for repaying the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Alma is married and has 5 school-aged children. To make a living, Alma owns and operates a general store where she sells a variety of daily-use products, such as shampoo, soap and toothpaste, in the local community. Alma has been engaged in her business for over 18 years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month for these activities.

Alma joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Alma is requesting a loan of 5000 PHPto purchase additional products to sell. This will be Alma's first loan from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Rosalie's Group

texts.en:
Rosalie D. is from the village of San Andres. She is 44 years old. Rosalie is the leader of a 7-member loan group sponsored by ASKI. Although each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are collectively responsible for repaying the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Rosalie D.'s Group.

Rosalie is married and has 5 school-aged children. To make a living, Rosalie owns and operates a general store where she sells a variety of different products in the local community. Rosalie has been engaged in her business for over 8 years and earns approximately 3500 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2008, Rosalie joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Rosalie has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Rosalie is requesting a new loan of 10000 PHP to purchase new items to expand her product offering. This will be Rosalie's fourth loan from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase new items to sell

loans.name: Estelita's Group

texts.en:
Estelita C. is from the village of San Andres. She is 47 years old. Estelita is the leader of a 7-member loan group sponsored by ASKI. Although each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are collectively responsible for repaying the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Estelita C. Group.

Estelita is married and has 1 adult child. To make a living, Estelita owns and operates a general store where she sells a variety of different products in the local community. Marilyn has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 4000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2007, Estelita joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Estelita has successfully repaid a previous loan of 18,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Estelita is requesting a new loan of 20000 PHP to purchase new items to her expand product offering. This loan will be the seventh loan taken out by Estelita from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase new items to expand her product offering

loans.name: Joel's Group

texts.en:
Joel A. is from the village of Catugay, Baggao, Cagayan. He is 32 years old. Joel is the leader of a 13-member loan group sponsored by ASKI. Although each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are collectively responsible for repaying the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Joel is married and has one young child. To make a living, Joel owns and operates a general store where she sells a variety of daily-use products, such as shampoo, soap and toothpaste, in the local community. Joel has been engaged in her business for over 2 years and earns approximately 3000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2010, Joel joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Joel is requesting a loan of 7000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Joel from ASKI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand his business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Amelia's Group

texts.en:
Amelia A. is from the village of Sto. Domingo. She is 35 years old. Amelia is the group leader of a 5-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. loans.name: Odiljon

texts.en: B. Odiljon is from Tursunzade, where he plants vegetables and raises cattle. Odiljon is married, with 4 children. He is a hard worker who has now doubled his efforts because he wants to increase his income to fulfill the needs of his family. Odiljon has asked for the support of Kiva partner IMON International through a loan that will allow him to buy materials for planting his crops as well as to invest in purchasing and raising cattle in his area. More about Tajikistan and IMON International Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It also has produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions. But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty. IMON's history Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low-income clients represent a viable business proposition. loans.name: Otabek

texts.en:
B. Otabek is 24 years old and married. For the past two years, he has owned a shop from which he sells spare moped engine parts. The income he earns allows him to support his family, including his parents. To meet his customers’ constantly growing demand, Otabek would like to increase his shop’s capacity. The profits from increased sales will allow him to continue to improve his living conditions. This loan will greatly improve Otabek’s income and his family's living standards.

More about Tajikistan
Tajikistan, a key post on the Silk Road, is perhaps best known for its rich history. It was the location for the end of Alexander the Great's rule, and is known for its great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets such as Rudaki, Ibn Sina (Avicenna), Firdousi, Omar Haiyam, Jomi, Mavlavi Rumi and many others. The country, with its epic mountain passes, is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language and a civilization that dates back to the fourth millennium BC. Even today, it is a complex mix of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

However, Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the USSR, damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93 per cent of the country is mountainous and only 7 per cent of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands of people to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

loans.name: Meltus

texts.en:
Meltus O. is a businessman who plants and sells maize in Musoma Nambale, Busia District. He used to be employed but retired to start this business in 2005 in order to generate income and provide for his wife and their seven children.
Meltus buys his stock twice a year during planting seasons. At 50 years old, Meltus still has lots of energy, but insufficient income to expand his business so as to ensure his economic stability and sustainability. Therefore, he is requesting a loan of 10,000 KES to increase and improve his business.

loans.use: To increase his stock of maize

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Zebo

texts.en:
Zebo is 46 years old and fights daily to increase her family's income so that her children have all that is necessary for a good life. She has always fought to provide for her family and educate her five children, two of whom are working adults today thanks to her example. Her perseverance has given her family the assurance that she does everything possible to make their lives pleasant.
Due to Zebo's hard work, she was able to purchase a small plot of land that she is farming together with her husband. However, the produce from the land has decreased and family expenses are using up the little capital they have. In turn, this has reduced the amount of money available for purchasing fuels, lubricants, seeds and fertilizers for the new plot of land in which they have invested. This is why Zebo is requesting a loan of 5000 TJS. The situation which Zebo finds herself in has made her ask for help, with the hope that she will find sensitive collaborators to help her get through these hard times.

loans.name: Erick

texts.en:
Erick O. is a businessman who lives and does business in Manyole village, Nambale, Busia District. He is 42 years old, married, and has seven children.
Erick started his dairy farming business back in June 2008, after trying a series of other businesses such as brick making and running a retail shop. These were all to no success as his profit margin was too low. However, since starting his dairy, things have been working out nicely with his stock of both pure and upgraded dairy cows. He buys supplies such as feed and drugs daily, since his products are also sold daily.
Due to the current demand for his products, Erick wants to add more cows to his herd. He wants to be able to expand his business to reach more customers, and therefore increase his profit margin in the long term. It is for this reason that he is requesting a loan of 20,000 KES.

loans.use: To buy more cows

John W. is 62 years old. He sells bricks, a business he started in 2003 in Manyole, Nambale, Busia District, where he also lives with his wife and eight children.

loans.name: Gulbazor

texts.en:
N. Gulbazor is 47 years old. She is the loving mother of three children. In order to help her husband support the large family, Gulbazor and her husband started their own business. So for the last 14 years, Gulbazor has been selling curtains. She has got her own sales point located in one of the local markets. Being a very friendly and polite person by nature, Gulbazor grew her clientele very quickly. The business is stable, generating the main income for the family. 

Today Gulbazor is planning to increase her working capital in order to expand her business. She needs additional funds for purchasing new styles of curtains to sell. With this purpose in mind, Gulbazor requests 8000 Somoni. Gulbazor has received loans from IMON several times and has proved herself a reliable client. She thanks all for their support and promises to be accurate in loan repayment.

Because Kong G. doesn't have capital yet, she requested a loan to purchase feed and piglets for her new stall. (Kong G. was not available when this photo was taken. So, her husband is pictured instead.)

Charity is very determined and wants to expand the size of her business. She is requesting a loan of $950 to purchase more inventory. This will help her attract more customers and make a better profit. She thanks all Kiva lenders for their support.

Abir is requesting a loan for $1,200 so she can expand her inventory and offer the new season's clothes and shoes to her clients. This will help her business create more profits. Abir loves being able to offer support to her family from her earnings.

loans.use: To purchase more inventory for clothing sales

texts.en:

Evelyn buys her products from wholesalers in Benin City, and some of her children help her transport them to her own shop. Her earnings help her husband provide support for the family.

Evelyn is requesting a loan for $350 to purchase more seed tomatoes to sell. She says thanks to all kiva lenders for their finance assistance

loans.use: To purchase more seed tomatoes

loans.name: Youssef

texts.en: Youssef is 20 years old and single. Since 2006, he has owned and operated a shop that sells mobile phones and accessories. He works hard to develop his business and is thankful for his revenues. Youssef helps his brother care for their mother. He is requesting a loan of $1,200  to update his inventory which will help him provide for more customers.

loans.use: To update inventory

loans.name: Pich

texts.en: Mrs. Pich O. is a humble farmer living in a village located the province of Kompong Tom. She has two teenaged children who attend the local public school. She and her husband grow and sell vegetables. She is requesting a loan of  $500  to buy a pumping machine because her farm is not located near a watering system, and she has problems irrigating her crops. A pumping system will improve her yield and help her increase her income.

loans.use: To buy a pumping machine to water crops

loans.name: Amidu

texts.en: To earn a living in Ibadan, Amidu sells engine oil at retail prices to his customers. He loves this business dearly and he hopes to expand in his business. Amidu sells his engine oil daily and he loves the one-on-one interaction that he has with his customers. He hopes for the loan amount of NGN 100,000 to purchase more engine oil to sell. He is 56 years old and married with 5 children. He is happy because some of his children are married and he is also a grandfather. He says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more engine oil to sell

loans.name: Chhoun

texts.en: Chhoun S. is a pig raiser and has been operating her sector from her home in the village since 2000. She is married to Mok Art, a construction worker. The family has five children, who are students. Chhoun S. and her family are living in an older house which often needs repair. She desires to mend her house and is asking for a loan to hire a repairman to mend her house.

loans.use: To hire a repairman to mend her house.

loans.name: Ilham

texts.en: Ilham is married. He is 47 years old. Ilham M. and his family live in Khachmaz region. Five years ago, he started a pharmacy. Now he needs a loan of 2000 AZN to buy more medicine to sell in his pharmacy in order to grow his business.

loans.use: to buy medicine to sell

loans.name: Dorcas

texts.en:
Dorcas makes lovely Nigerian and western hair styles for her customers. She also sells hair extensions and creams. She opens her salon daily from 8 am to 7 pm. She hopes to own a world class salon in the future. She loves her business because she makes her customers look beautiful. 

Dorcas hopes for the loan amount of NGN 100,000 to purchase more hair extensions to sell. Dorcas is 38 years old and married with 3 children. Her eldest child is 10 years old while the youngest is 3 years old. Her children are doing well in school. Her husband repairs refrigerators and he also supports their home. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more hair extensions to sell

loans.name: Funke

texts.en:
Funke sells groceries at retail prices to her customers to make a living. She hopes to own a supermarket in the future. She has been in this business for a long time and she uses her years of experience to attract and retain customers. She is 54 years old, married with 3 children. Her eldest child is 34 years old. Her children are excelling in business and school and this makes her happy. She is also happy because she is a grand mother. 

Funke loves this business because of the one-on-one interaction she has with her customers. She is requesting the loan amount of NGN 100,000 to purchase more groceries to sell. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more groceries to sell

loans.name: Bugema B Wabule Base Group

texts.en: W. Base is a hard-working businesswoman of thirty-six, married with six children of whom five are schooling. She deals with produce such as rice and she has been in this business for over fifteen years so far. She is using the loan to inject more capital into her business as well purchasing bags of rice to market. Her future hope is to continue to educate her children.

loans.use: To inject more capital into her business as well purchasing bags of rice for resale

loans.name: Tes

texts.en:
Tes N. sells fresh fish that she either gets from her husband’s fishing or buys from other fishermen. In order to earn extra proceeds, Tes N. is looking for assistance via Kiva’s field partner, HKL. She will be using her loan to buy a plot of land in a good location for farming, which she will then rent to other farmers for a fee. 

Tes N. is married with six children. She has established a medium-sized house where she lives with other family members in Kompong Tom province. (Mrs. Tes N. was not available for taking a photo, so her husband is pictured instead.)

loans.use: To buy a plot of farm land

loans.name: Kyoterekera Omunaku Farida Kayegi Group

texts.en: Farida K. is the Group Representative for 'Kyoterekera Omunaku Group'. She is a hard-working business lady of twenty-eight years old. She is married, with three children, of whom two are going to school, and she has two dependents who are also schooling. She has a restaurant business and she has been in her business for over two years. She is using the loan to purchase foodstuffs for her restaurant. She is encouraging and hard-working and her future hope is to expand her business.

loans.use: To purchase foodstuffs for her restaurant

loans.name: Iyabo

texts.en:
Iyabo is 38 years old and a mother of two. Her husband works at the Ministry of Works, Lagos State. She sells cooked food; until recently, she hawked cooked food from place to place but could sell only the little quantity she could carry. After she joined LAPO Microfinance, she was able to own a sales point.

Iyabo opens her stall every week day, from the hour of 8am to 6pm except on Sundays when she normally takes her rest. Her greatest priority has been to feed her children and make sure their school fees are paid.

Iyabo is asking for a loan of NGN100, 000 to purchase more foodstuffs in bulk (at a reduced rate) to cook and sell. This, she said, will enable her to meet the demand of her customers and also increase her profit. She says thank you to Kiva lenders and LAPO Microfinance.

loans.use: To purchase more foodstuffs

loans.name: Nov

texts.en: Mr. Nov S. is fully able to feed his family by cultivating crops on his land next to his house. He has a partner in his wife who helps to conduct his business. They are married and have four children. All of them are going to school or work. Nov S. needs a pump to irrigate his crops, but he doesn’t have money yet to buy one. Thus he is applying for a loan with which he will buy a pump and other farming supplies for his business.

loans.use: To buy a pump and other farming supplies

loans.name: Nike

texts.en:
Nike weaves and sells the traditional cloth of the Yoruba’s called ‘aso-oke’. This cloth comes in various colors and it is worn in Nigeria on various occasions. Nike also sells cooking oil at retail prices to her customers. With these combined businesses, she hopes to meet the basic needs of her family. She is a friendly and hard-working woman. She hopes to expand her business. 

Nike hopes for the loan amount of NGN 50,000 to purchase more cooking oil to sell. She has a good relationship with LAPO. She is 33 years old and married with 3 children. Her children are excelling in school. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more cooking oil to sell

loans.name: Sin

texts.en: Mr. Sin S. is selling and buying recyclable goods (used goods) in the village to earn a living. In addition, his wife (who appears in the photo) raises a few pigs in a stall behind their house.  The couple have three kids; all of them are studying in school. Sin S. needs a loan in order to pay the expenses of repairing and decorating his old house, which often needs repair.

loans.use: To pay the expenses of repairing and decorating his old house

loans.name: Loh-E-Baba Jan Group

texts.en:
Nooria is a member of 'Loh-e-baba jan' group. She is 48 years old. She is married and the mother of 4 children, two daughters and two sons. Her sons are students and her daughters support her in her business. She is busy at carpet weaving. She has had experience in carpet weaving for more than 21 years and she is really skillful, but because of not having complete supplies she couldn’t progress well.

She needs the loan to purchase another new loom and other needed materials. She is glad that through this loan she will be able to increase her income and she hopes to grow her business in a short period of time and be able to send her sons to university after their graduation from school.

loans.use: purchasing a new loom

loans.name: Lani

texts.en:
Lani S. is a married woman who supports her family with her general store and farming businesses. She lives in Brgy Culipapa, Hinobaan, Negros Occidental with her husband and their 7 children who are 13 to 27 years old, with 3 of them having their own families, while the other 4 are currently going to school.

She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2003 and has improved her family's living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her general store and farming businesses, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of Php 10,000.

Lani is now borrowing Php 10,000 so that she can expand her general store. This will be her 14th loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of Php 9,000, which she paid off within its term, was just another step in her journey towards economic freedom.  Lani aspires to elevate her family’s living conditions and ensure their future well-being by following the “Dungganon” way.  

About NWTF:

In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress out of earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: Additional working capital

loans.name: Evelyn

texts.en:
Evelyn H. is a 42-year-old married woman who lives in Bongalonan, Basay, Negros Oriental. She earns her living through her general store and rice retailing businesses.

Evelyn’s 57-year-old husband, Ramon, works abroad.  They have 1 child who is currently going to school and also helps the mother in the business as part of the daily chores.

Evelyn joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2007 in the hope that she would be able to help her husband improve the quality of life of their family. With the help of her loans from NWTF-PD she has been able to increase their family income by engaging in her general store and rice retailing businesses. She now earns an average monthly income of Php 4,000 from her business activities.

Evelyn is a member in good standing. Her previous loan of Php 15,000 was used to fund operations for her general store which has had a positive impact in both the business and the family’s living conditions. Now she is borrowing her 6th loan in the amount of Php 16,000, which she intends to use for her general store and rice retailing businesses. Evelyn is working hard to achieve her dreams and aspirations for her family, which is to provide them with a brighter future and a more comfortable life.

About NWTF:

In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress out of earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: Additional working capital

loans.name: Abiola

texts.en: Abiola sells motor spare parts at retail prices. With his sales, he hopes to make his business sustainable. He is happy about his business because he is the only man in this business in his community. He hopes for a loan amount of NGN 150,000 to purchase more motor spare parts to sell. He is itching for progress in his business. He is 43 years old and married with 4 children. His wife sells building materials to help support their household. He says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more motor spare part to sell

loans.name: Twekembe Namono Rose Group

texts.en: N. Rose is a hard-working business lady of twenty-eight years old. She is married with three children of whom one child is going to school and moreover, she has one dependent schooling, too. She deals with the business of buying onions from villages sell at the market. She is using the loan to purchase onions from villages to resell. She is a determined businesswoman whose future hope is to expand on her business.

loans.use: To purchase onions from villages to bring to market

loans.name: Gemma

texts.en:
Gemma is a married woman who supports her family through her buying and selling fish business together with her husband.   Whatever catch her husband brings back for the day, Gemma is the one who sells it in the market or even in their community. She lives in Bongalanon Basay, Negros Oriental with her husband and their 8 children, with some of them already working while the others are currently going to school.

She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2007 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her fish vending business, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of Php 15,000.

Gemma is now borrowing Php 20,000 so that she can expand her fish vending and for the repair of her pump boat. This will be her 6th loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of Php 12,000, which she paid off within its term, was just another step in her journey towards economic freedom. Gemma aspires to elevate her family’s living conditions and ensure their future well-being by following the “Dungganon” way.  

About NWTF:

In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress out of earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: Additional working capital and repair of pump boat

loans.name: Solade

texts.en:
K. sells drinks and foodstuffs like beans, corn, tomatoes, pepper, 'gari' (cassava couscous), rice, and yam flour. She buys in large quantity and sells retail. She is very hard-working. On days she buy her goods from the market for her shop, she leaves her home as early as 5 am to enable her to get goods to buy. She has been in the business for ten years and with this she has been able to help her husband in providing for the family. K. hopes to improve and expand her business in future.

She is requesting a loan of NGN 70,000 to purchase more drinks and foodstuffs to sell. K. is 36 years old, married and blessed with two children. She appreciative to all KIVA lenders for their support.

loans.use: To purchase more drinks and foodstuffs to sell

loans.name: Hussein

texts.en:
Hussein is a 21-year-old single man living with his parents. In 2008, he decided to open a small mini-market in his town after seeing a need for such services in the region. His mini-market is situated in a busy area, so he has been able, during this short period, to have a growing number of customers pass by his shop and buy all types of food products. 

Today, Hussein is requesting to borrow US$ 1,000 to increase his purchases of such items as food products, soft drinks, juices etc. to increase his sales and make a good income for his family.

loans.use: increase his inventory

loans.name: Elena

texts.en:
Elena A. is a married woman who supports her family with her bakery, rolling store selling dried fish, and her hog raising. She lives in Brgy Man-uling Cuayan, Negros Occidental with her 47-year-old husband, Benigno, who also manages the rolling store for dried fish and with their 6 children who are all school-age.

Elena has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 1990 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her bakery, rolling dried fish store, and hog-raising businesses, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of Php 9,000.

Elena is now borrowing Php 25,000 so that she can expand her bakery, rolling dried fish store, and hog raising businesses. This will be her 21st loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of Php 25,000, which she paid off within its term, was just another step in her journey towards economic freedom. Elena aspires to elevate her family’s living conditions and ensure their future well-being by following the “Dungganon” way.  

About NWTF:

In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress out of earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: Additional working capital

loans.name: Rustam

texts.ru: Нодиров Рустам проживает в районе Вахдат. Возраст, 40 лет. Женат, имеет 2 детей. Жена, занимается пошивкой национальных платьев. Сам Рустам более 10 лет занимается торговлей. У него свой магазин, где он продает продукты. В этом ему помогает сын. Кредит берет для увеличения товараоборота. Рустам хочет увеличить ассортимент своего товара. Так как этим он привлечет внимание новых клиентов и получит хороший доход.
texts.en:
N. Rustam lives in the Vahdat region. He's forty years old, married and has two children. His wife sows national dresses. For more than ten years Rustam has been working in sales: He has his own store, where he sells groceries. His son helps him in the store. Rustam is asking for a loan to increase his goods turnover. He also wishes to increase the variety of his products, so that he may attract more customers and increase his profits.

Translated from Russian by Alex Kostrubsky, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To increase goods turnover

loans.name: Victoria

texts.en:
Victoria S. is 50-year-old married woman who lives in Bungyod Brgy 2, Himamaylan City, Negros Occidental. She earns her living through her pig-fattening and general store businesses.

Together with Victoria’s husband, Romulo, and their 8 children (with some of them already working and having their own families while the others are still in school) they have been able to grow the business together as the children help out making it part of their daily chores.

Victoria joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2007 in the hope that she would be able to help her husband improve the quality of life of their family. With the help of her loans from NWTF-PD, she has been able to increase their family income by engaging in her general store and pig-fattening businesses. Now she earns an average monthly income of Php 4,000 from her business activities.

Victoria is a member in good standing. Her previous loan of Php 10,000 was used to fund operations for her general store and pig-fattening which had a positive impact in both the business and the family’s living conditions. Now she is borrowing her 6th loan in the amount of Php 10,000, which she intends to use on her general store and pig-fattening. Victoria is working hard to achieve her dreams and aspirations for her family, which are to provide them with a brighter future and a more comfortable life.

About NWTF:

In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress out of earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed on a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: Additional working capital

loans.name: Dupe

texts.en:
Dupe is a businesswoman. She sells drinks at retail prices to her customers. She loves this business because she does not sell on credit and so she does not incur debt in her business. She hopes to own a drink company in the future. She hopes for the loan amount of NGN 100,000 to purchase more drinks to sell. She is a friendly and happy woman. She uses her friendly nature to attract and retain more customers to her business. 

Dupe is married with 3 children. Her children are excelling in school and business. To help his wife support the family, Dupe’s husband sells plates and pots. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more drinks to sell

loans.name: Alie

texts.en:
Alie is a 37-year-old trader dealing in footwear. He has been in this business for the last eight years.  He is married with 4 children.  He buys his stock from a wholesaler in Freetown and retails the footwear.  

Alie sells his goods mainly moving around through villages on market days; while he is away, his wife superintends the business at its permanent location in town.  The family uses proceeds from the business for its livelihood especially for sending the children to school.  

Alie wants this loan to rent a store in the main market and also to increase his stock.  Alie is believed to be trustworthy and resilient in his business.

loans.use: to rent a store in the main market and to increase his inventory

loans.name: Rosemarie

texts.en:
Rosemarie C. is a married woman who supports her family through her general store, buying and selling charcoal, and their “habal-habal” - a mode of transportation with a single motorcycle. She lives in Brgy. Mahalang, Himamaylan City, Negros Occidental with her husband Joemarie and their 7 children who are all school-aged.

Rosemarie has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2003 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard at her general store, buying and selling charcoal ,and their “habal-habal”, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of Php 15,000.

Rosemarie is now borrowing Php 20,000 so that she can use the loan for the repair of a their motorcycle for the 'habal-habal' business. This will be her 15th loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of Php 20,000, which she paid off within its term, was just another step in her journey towards economic freedom. Rosemarie aspires to elevate her family’s living conditions and ensure their future well-being by following the “Dungganon” way.  

About NWTF:

In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress out of earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed on a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: to repair their motorcycle transport vehicle

loans.name: Oladago

texts.en:
Oladago is married to a food seller and they have 6 children. Oladago is not only a father and husband, he is also a grandfather and this makes him happy and proud. He has a good relationship with LAPO. 

To make a living in Ibadan, he sells rams. He loves this business because of the one-on-one interaction that he has with his customers. He is itching for progress in his business and he hopes to expand that business.  He hopes for the loan amount of NGN 150,000 to purchase more rams to sell. He says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more rams to sell

loans.name: Abu Bakarr

texts.en:
Abu Bakarr was born in 1972, and he started school five years later, but his father died when he was in class five.  No family member was willing to continue to support his schooling after the death of his father, so he became a dropout.  

At the age of fifteen, he decided to join his uncle in hawking costume jewelry.  Later a friend who admired his courage decided to consign some goods to him.  After 8 years, he has been able to set up his own small jewelry business.  He is determined to expand his business with this loan if he is successful and to send his 5 children to school

loans.use: To buy jewelry for resale

loans.name: Mary Ann

texts.en:
Mary Ann V. is a married woman who supports her family by running a general store. She lives in Pob Mabinay, Negros Oriental with her husband Hoswe, 35 years old and a tricycle (three-wheeled transport) driver.

She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2002 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her general store business, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of Php 10,000.

Mary Ann is now borrowing Php 23,000 so that she can expand her general store. This will be her 9th loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of Php 22,000, which she paid off within its term, was just another step in her journey towards economic freedom. Mary Ann aspires to elevate her family’s living conditions and ensure their future well-being by following the “Dungganon” way.  

About NWTF:

In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress out of earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: Additional working capital

loans.name: Pius

texts.en:
Pius K. is the proprietor of a mini-boutique. This shop is rented within the central business district.

He is married and his wife is also engaged in the running of the boutique. He spends part of his time as a social worker with a non-governmental organization (NGO) in Bo.

He has two years' experience in business. He hopes to use the proceeds of the loan to purchase land and educate his children.

He is industrious and hard-working.

loans.use: To buy additional clothing for resale

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Twekembe Nambozo Sarah Group

texts.en: N. Sarah is a hard-working business lady of twenty-six, married with two children schooling, and she has three dependents schooling, too. She operates a produce business selling groundnuts. She has been in business for over five years. She is using the loan to purchase groundnuts from farmers and stock them for sale. The loan is improving her business. She is an encouraging business lady whose dream is to educate her children.

loans.use: To purchase groundnuts from farmers and stock them for resale

loans.name: Ibrahim

texts.en: In 2008, Ibrahim, a 24-year-old single man, decided to open his own men's clothing sales shop to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities.  With those goals met, Ibrahim is now requesting a loan of $800 to increase his inventory and buy more clothes such as jeans, tee shirts, sweaters etc. to attract more clients and continue to meet his clientele's various needs.

loans.use: To increase his inventory and buy more clothes

loans.name: Omolola

texts.en:
Omolola owns a shop where she styles hair and sells hair extensions and other hair accessories. In 2005, she started this business to make a living in Lagos State, Nigeria. She buys hair accessories from certified distributors and sells them at a retail price. She hopes for a business expansion in the future.

Omolola hopes for a loan in the amount of 70,000 NGN in order to purchase more hair extensions directly from the manufacturers at a very reduced rate. Omolola is 29 years old and married to Mr. J., who is a civil servant. She thanks Kiva lenders for their financial assistance.

loans.use: To purchase more hair extensions to sell

loans.name: Hammed

texts.en: Hammed O. is a hardworking 52-year-old man. He is married with four children. His children attend school, and they are excelling in their school. His wife sells foodstuffs to support their home. To improve his family's living standard, he sells blocks in his community in Ibadan. He loves this business because of the profits, and he hopes to expand his business in the future by adding the sale of sand. He hopes for a loan in the amount of 100,000 NGN in order to purchase more blocks to sell. Hammed's only challenge is a lack of funds, and he hopes to overcome that challenge. He says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more blocks to sell

loans.name: Fanta

texts.en:
Fanta F. is a trader who trades in garrie (made from cassava tubers), cigarettes, and provisions. She buys cigarettes from Freetown (the capital of Sierra Leone) and Guinea. On her return, she sells her garrie in Conakry (the capital of Guinea).

She is married to a miner, and they have three children. Her business is located at the center of the business park in Bo.

She has 10 years of business experience in garrie export.

With this loan, she wants to buy additional stock and then use the proceeds from the loan to increase her capital and to support her son's education.

She has spent half of her lifetime in business and is very much committed to her business.

loans.use: To buy garrie, cigarettes, and provisions

loans.name: Dilshod

texts.ru: Кутбидинов Дилшод проживает в районе Вахдат. Возраст, 24 года. Холост. Имеет среднее образование. Более 5 лет занимается торговлей. В основном продает запастные части автомашины. Этот бизнес приносит доход. Кредит берет для увеличения товараоборота. Дилшод хочет увеличить ассортимент, так как спрос на запасные части новых моделей автомашин увеличился.
texts.en:
K. Dilshod lives in the Vahdat region. He's twenty-four years old and single. He has a high school education. For more than five years he has been in sales: in general, he sells automotive spare parts. This is a profitable business. He is asking for a loan to increase his goods turnover. Dilshod wishes to provide more variety in his products, because the demand for spare parts of new models of cars has recently increased.

Translated from Russian by Alex Kostrubsky, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To increase goods turnover

loans.name: Toyin

texts.en:
Toyin is a hardworking businesswoman. She sells drinks at retail prices to her customers. She loves this business, because she does not sell on credit. Thus, she does not incur debt in her business. She hopes to own a drink company in the future. She hopes for a loan amount of 100,000 NGN in order to purchase more drinks to sell. She is a friendly and happy woman. She uses her friendly nature to attract and retain more customers to her business. She is married with four children, and she is 48 years old. Her children are excelling in school and business.

Toyin has a good relationship with the Lift Above Poverty Organization (LAPO). LAPO is committed to improving lives in Nigeria and elsewhere in Africa. Toyin says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more drinks to sell

loans.name: Charbel

texts.en: Charbel has worked as an electrician for the past 15 years. He works on a freelance basis serving homes and shops upon request of his clients. He is well known in his town and the neighboring villages. He is 30 years old, single, and his family's sole provider. Today, Charbel has found an opportunity to expand his business into other areas and take on more projects. To do so, he's asking for a loan of $1,200 to buy new tools instead of the used ones he has now.

loans.use: buy new tools

loans.name: Abasat

texts.en: Abasat I. lives in the Fuzuli region. Born in 1978, he is single and has been in the retail business for three years. Now he needs a loan of 2000 AZN to expand the inventory of his general store.

loans.use: to buy goods

loans.name: Shehu

texts.en: Shehu M. is the proprietor of a store in the central business district of Bo, Sierra Leone. He sells vehicle spare parts and used furniture. He is married and has four dependents. His wife also works for the business. He imports his parts from the U.S and Europe and wants to increase sales of these imports which make him higher profits. He hopes the loan will help him pay his kids' school fees and buy land for future development.

loans.use: To buy additional spare parts

loans.name: Hassan

texts.en:
Hassan M. is trader who trades in men’s wear (jeans, t-shirts, etc). He is married and his wife helps in the business on a daily basis. They have two kids.

The stall where he sells his clothing is located at O.I.C gate within the central business district of Bo. He has five years of business experience in men’s wear.

He is seeking a loan to increase his stock as well as increase his sales.

He hopes to use the proceeds of the loan to pay his sons' school fees and to help them pursue their tertiary education.

He is keen to succeed in business as he spends his life on this business.

loans.use: To buy used clothing

loans.name: Haron

texts.en:
Haron K. was born in 1966. He is married to Susan Bowen who was born in 1966 and is a primary school teacher.  They have five kids between them who are aged between 18 years and 10 years. 

Haron runs a medical laboratory, which he opened in 1998, and he gets a profit of Kshs 20,000 from this business. He gets additional income from his salary from the hospital where he works as a laboratory attendant. 

Haron was introduced to Kadet by a friend. Apart from Kadet, he has also borrowed from his workplace cooperative before. He has borrowed a loan, which he plans to use to restock his laboratory with reagents and to buy a machine that will enable him to do some medical tests that he couldn’t do before.

loans.use: To buy labaratory reagents

loans.name: Alice

texts.en:
Alice is a 40-year-old single woman. She lives with her mother and she is the only provider for her after the death of her father. She has owned an accessories and perfumes shop in her town since 1988. During this long period, she has gained a large number of clients passing by her shop. 

Today, Alice is requesting to borrow $1,000 to buy more merchandise to meet her clients’ demands and offer all the new items for them.

loans.use: To buy more merchandise for her shop.

loans.name: Kehinde

texts.en: Kehinde is married to a painter and they have five children. Her eldest child is 15 years old. Her children are still young and they are dependent on her. Kehinde is 45 years old and she is hard working. She sells foodstuffs like rice, beans and garri (cassava flakes). She sells for long hours to enable her to support her home. She hopes for a loan of N50,000 to purchase more foodstuffs to sell. She hopes to expand her business and family life. She has a good relationship with LAPO (Lift Above Poverty Organization), which is committed to improving lives in Nigeria and elsewhere in Africa. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more foodstuffs to sell

loans.name: Latofat

texts.ru: Газабова Латофат проживает в районе Вахдат. Возраст. 45 лет. Вдова, имеет 4 детей. Старший сын предоставляет услугу, такси. Сама Латофат более 6 лет занимается торговлей. Она в основном торгует продуктами питания. В этом ей помогают дети. Кредит берет для увеличения товараоборота.
texts.en:
G. Latofat lives in the Vahdat region. She's forty-five years old. She is a widow and has four children. Her oldest son works as a taxi driver. For more than six years Latofat has been involved in commerce, mainly selling foodstuffs. She is assisted by her children. Latofat is asking for a loan to increase her goods turnover.

Translated from Russian by Alex Kostrubsky, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To increase goods turnover

loans.name: Bidemi

texts.en: Bidemi sells groceries and foodstuffs at retail prices to her customers to make a living. She hopes to own a supermarket in the future. She has been in this business for a long time and she uses her years of experience to attract and retain customers. She is 38 years old and married with a child. Her child is 10 years old and attends school and this makes her happy. She loves this business because of the one-on-one interaction she has with her customers. She is requesting a loan of NGN 150,000 to purchase more groceries and foodstuffs to sell. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more foodstuffs and groceries to sell

loans.name: Khadijat

texts.en: Selling clothes is a business activity that Khadijat J. loves so much. She loves this business because of her interaction with her customers. She hopes to own a boutique in the future. She is itching for progress and expansion in her business. She is hoping for a loan of NGN 100,000 to purchase more clothes to sell. Khadijat is 28 years old and married with three children. Her youngest child is two years old. Her children are still young and dependent on her. Her husband also works to support their home. She duly thanks all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more clothes to sell

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
Elizabeth has a shop where she sells drinks. She buys in bulk and sells at retail to her customers.
