Rafaela plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay her children’s tuition fees. About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has twenty-one branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase livestock feeds

loans.name: Lilian

texts.en:
Lilian E., 60, is making sure that her family has enough provisions for their daily needs. She is married to Alfredo E., a school utility personnel, and they are blessed with four children. She makes sure that she helps her husband earn money so that their family can have a better life. She has been selling Filipino rice cake delicacies for several years.

Lilian has been a regular member of Center for Community Transformation* (CCT) for more than a year now. She regularly attends their weekly fellowship meetings and pays her weekly dues consistently. Because of her good repayment performance with her previous loans, she has been able to borrow three times in CCT’s Cooperative. She has been consistent in paying her dues because she used the money she borrowed as added ingredients for her food vending business. Her business lets her earn a profit of PHP 3,900 per month.

Now with your help, she would like to apply for a PHP 8,000 loan. This amount will be used as a source of added capital to her expanding business by buying key ingredients for her food vending business.

She dreams that her business will grow for a better life in the future.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To buy key ingredients for her food vending business

loans.name: Aminalah

texts.en:
Aminalah is the son of S.. He lives in district 8 of Kabul, Afghanistan. He is 54 years old and has four children who are in school. He wants to take out a loan for his business, as he needs to buy different kinds of beverages for his shop. He has a general store in which he sells different kinds of things. He wants to expand his business and buy more materials, especially the things that are more in demand. At the same time, he wants to attract more clients.

He is happy that there is a nice process that can solve entrepreneurs’ problems. He wants to make his shop larger to help with his families. So he is very happy about this process of small loans in Afghanistan and wants to thank everyone, especially the Kiva lenders around world.

loans.use: To expand and progress his business

loans.name: Bayasgalan

texts.en:
Bayasgalan is 48 years old and lives with her husband and their four children in Arhangai province, Mongolia. She and her family live together in a 'ger', the Mongolian nomadic tent. Their oldest daughter has graduated from university in Mongolia. 

In 2000, Bayasgalan started a sewing business with a working capital of 500,000 tugrugs (~ 351 USD), but after a lot of hard work her working capital currently exceeds 3,000,000 tugrugs (~ 2111 USD). Her successful business has allowed her to pay the tuition fees of her twins and to afford family expenses. 

Bayasgalan is a very hard-working and loyal person who has a great business mind. She says “I would like to be a reliable person who doesn't break promises.” Bayasgalan is requesting a 1,200,000 tugrug (~ 844 USD) loan to purchase a large amount of materials for her sewing business.

loans.use: To purchase materials for her sewing business

loans.name: Joan

texts.en:
Joan M., 29, is making sure that her family has enough to cover their daily needs. Married to Joseph M. who works at a printing press, she is blessed with two children. She makes sure that she helps her husband earn their living so that their family can have a better life.  She has managed her own variety store for several years.

Joan has been a regular member of Center for Community Transformation* (CCT) for more than two years now. She regularly attends their weekly fellowship meetings and pays her weekly dues consistently. Because of her good repayment performance with her previous loans, she was able to borrow eight times through CCT’s Cooperative.  She is consistent in paying her dues because she uses the money she borrows in buying added stock for her business.   Her business lets her earn a profit of PHP 8,000 per month.  

Now with your help, she would like to apply for a PHP 18,000 loan. This amount will be used as a source of added working capital for her expanding business by buying more stock for her store.

She dreams that her business will continue to grow so that she can finance her children’s schooling until they graduate from college. 


* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: buying more assorted products for her store

loans.name: Sungulu Juma

texts.en:
Sungulu is a 51-year-old married lady and a mother to four children; two grown up and two who are still going to school. Both Sungulu and her husband are farmers which is their primary business. Sungulu also sells cereals as a secondary business from which she gets a total profit of Kshs 4,000 per month. She sells to residents of Gongoni-Malindi area.

She was introduced to Kadet by an existing member and is on her third loan. Sungulu has previously borrowed from KWFT. She has applied for a loan which she will use in the following manner: Kshs 20000 to purchase cereals for resale; Kshs 3000 to prepare land and Kshs 7000 to buy seeds and fertilizer for planting. She plans to continue expanding her business with the extra income she will get from this loan.

Sungulu describes herself as hard-working and she hopes to build business premises and invest in dairy farming.

loans.use: To purchase cereals for resale, prepare land, buy seeds and fertilizers for planting

loans.name: Tarcisia

texts.en:
Tarcisia O., 60, is making sure that she works not just for herself but to help others as well. She has been selling vegetables, fish, and meat in the market for three years. 

Tarcisia has been a regular member of Center for Community Transformation* (CCT) for more than two years now. She regularly attends their weekly fellowship meetings and pays her weekly dues consistently. Because of her good repayment performance with her previous loans, she has been able to borrow seven times through CCT’s Cooperative.  She is consistent in paying her dues because she uses the money she borrows as added working capital for her business. Her business lets her earn a profit of PHP 8,600 per month.  

Now with your help, she would like to apply for a PHP 10,000 loan. This amount will be used as a source of added capital to her expanding business, allowing her to buy more vegetables, fish, and meat.

She prays for good health and that her business will grow so that she can continue to help other relatives who are depending on her for assistance. 

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: buying more vegetables, fish, and meat

loans.name: Poni

texts.en:
Poni L. is currently in the business of selling local alcoholic beverages at the market and is requesting a loan to stock materials to use to make more alcohol to sell.  Poni is 20 years old and is married to a husband who is a businessman. She has 3 children and two of her children go to school. One is in baby class and another one is in primary one (1).  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open a bar and restaurant.

 BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education , and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  

In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: Stock materials to use to make more alcohol to sell

loans.name: Nenita

texts.en:
Nenita G., 49, is making sure that her family has enough for their daily needs. Married to Edwin G., a foreman construction worker, she is  blessed with five children. She makes sure that she helps her husband earn their living so that their family can have a better life.  She has been selling cooked food and managing her own variety store for several years.

Nenita has been a regular member of Center for Community Transformation* (CCT) for more than two years now. She regularly attends their weekly fellowship meetings and pays her weekly dues consistently. Because of her good repayment performance with her previous loans, she has been able to borrow six times through CCT’s Cooperative.  She is consistent in paying her dues because she uses the money she borrows as added working capital for her business. Her business lets her earn a profit of PHP 6,700 per month.  

Now with your help, she would like to apply for a PHP 16,000 loan. This amount will be used as a source of added working capital for her expanding business, allowing her to buy more food and products for her store.

She dreams that her business will continue to grow so that they can save enough to cover their  children’s education. 

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: buying more food and products for her store

loans.name: James

texts.en:
James M. K. is fifty years old. He is married and they have two children aged twenty-three and twenty-one years old. His business is located at Kiganjo, a very business market in Thika. Thika is the region in Kenya known for production of pineapples.


James has been running a fuel station for the last five years. He says the major challenge in this kind of business is price fluctuations therefore dissatisfied customers. However, he works very hard to keep his business doing well. He is using his loan of Kes 65,000 to buy fuel to expand his business. In future, he hopes to open many outlets. He is a very innovative man.

loans.use: buying more fuel to resell

loans.name: Ann

texts.en: Ann is 45 years old, widowed, and has three children to take care of.  Two of the children attend school.   She has been selling cereals retail for two years.   She previously owned a retail shop. She also earns extra income through employment.   She hopes to build residential houses in future.    She has requested a loan of Kes 40,000 to add more stock of cereals such as maize and beans.    She describes herself as hard-working and sociable.

loans.use: Add to her inventory

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary A. is currently in the business of selling sugar and onions at the market and is requesting a loan to purchase bags of rice to sell.  Mary is 25 years old and is married to a husband who is a businessman. She has 3 children and her children go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open a wholesale shop.

 BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  

In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: purchase bags of rice to sell

loans.name: Adija

texts.en:
Adija sells foodstuffs like bags of rice and cooking oil at retail prices. She is happy in her business because of the opportunity to interact with her customers. She hopes for the loan amount of NGN 80,000 to purchase more foodstuffs to sell. She hopes to grow her business. 

Adija is 56 years old; she is married to a commercial driver and they have 5 children. Adija is not only a wife and a mother, she is also a grandmother and this gives her joy. She hopes to lift her business and her family above poverty. She is indeed grateful to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more foodstuffs to sell

loans.name: Ibish

texts.en: Ibish O. is 32 years old. He is married and has 2 children. Ibish O. and his family live in Fuzuli region. He has been in the auto repair business for 4 years. Now Ibish needs a loan of 2000 AZN to buy spare auto parts to expand his business.

loans.use: to buy spare auto parts

loans.name: Fadekemi

texts.en:
To earn a living in Ibadan, Fadekemi sells foodstuffs at retail prices. She is happy in her business because of the opportunity to interact with her customers. She hopes for the loan amount of NGN 80,000 to purchase more foodstuffs to sell. She hopes to grow her business. She hopes to a major foodstuffs distributor in the future. 

Fadekemi is 39 years old and married to a teacher. Her husband also supports their home. Her three children are schooling and this gives her joy. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more foodstuffs to sell

loans.name: Saada

texts.en: Saada is a 45-year-old single mother of five children who attend school.  She sells charcoal in Machakos, a business she has been running for two years.  She plans to add more charcoal stocks and start a greengrocer shop, hence she has requested a loan of Kes.20,000.  Her dream is to own a house in the future.  She describes herself as hard-working.

loans.use: Add stocks of charcoal and start a grocery store

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Enhtaivan

texts.en:
Enhtaivan is 51 years old and lives with his wife and their three children in Arhangai province, Mongolia. He and his family live together in a 'ger', the Mongolian nomadic tent. His wife operates a consumer goods retailing business. 

Enhtaivan started a wooden furniture manufacturing business in 2002 with a working capital of 800,000 tugrugs (~ 562 USD). After a lot of hard work, his working capital currently exceeds 3,200,000 tugrugs (~ 2251 USD). With his new earnings, he has purchased tools used to produce wooden products which is a more effective way for him to operate his business. In addition, he has purchased his own plot of land with a yard, where he has created his own workplace.  

Enhtaivan is a very hard-working person and says, “I'm working hard to continue to pay my children's tuition fees and to convert our 'ger' [the traditional Mongolian nomadic tent] into a house in the future. I have already started to purchase the necessary materials to build my own house for my family.”  

Enhtaivan's son supports him and his business. Enhtaivan is requesting an 800,000 tugrug (~ 562  USD) loan to purchase a large amount of materials to manufacture wooden products for his customers.

loans.use: To purchase wood

loans.name: Clarisa

texts.en:
Clarisa A., 45, is making sure that her family has enough for their daily needs. Married to Wilfredo A., she is blessed with four children. She makes sure that she helps her husband earn their living so that their family can have a better life.  Together they have been managing their own variety store for several years.

Clarisa has been a regular member of Center for Community Transformation* (CCT) for more than a year now. She regularly attends their weekly fellowship meetings and pays her weekly dues consistently. Because of her good repayment performance with her previous loans, she has been able to borrow four times through CCT’s Cooperative.  She is consistent in paying her dues because she uses the money she borrows to buy added stocks for her store.   Her business lets her earn a profit of PHP 3,900 per month.  

Now with your help, she would like to apply for a PHP 10,000 loan. This amount will be used as a source of added working capital for her expanding business, allowing her to buy assorted products for her variety store.

She dreams that her business will be more successful for a better family standard of living. 

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: buying assorted products for her variety store

loans.name: Nike

texts.en:
Thirty-four years old, Nike is married and has a child aged 10 years. Nike sells snacks and drinks in a private secondary school in Lagos State to earn a living. She has been in this business for the past six years. She leaves home early to purchase snacks for the day’s business. She said the school children patronize her because her drinks are always cold and her snacks are nice. She hopes for business expansion.

Nike wants the loan amount of NGN 80,000 to purchase more drinks and snacks to sell as this will help increase her income. She promises to pay back the loan when due. She thanks Kiva lenders for their assistance.

loans.use: To purchase more drinks and snacks to sell.

loans.name: Esther

texts.en:
Esther W. W. is twenty-eight years old. She is married and they have two children aged six years old and four months old whom they would wish to give good education someday. Her business is located at Mukuru kwa Njenga, Nairobi, Kenya. 

Her business is situated in a slum area but Esther is able to get many customers. It is well known by the name of Hunter Boutique. She has been selling men's and ladies' shoes, trousers, shirts, tops, handbags, and mattresses for the last nine years to the local people. She says that this business is profitable and the major challenge is lack of enough working capital. However she works very hard to keep her business doing well. 

Esther is using her loan of Kes 40,000 to buy more shoes to grow her business. She has plans to open new shops and even move the one out of the slums and locate it by the highway. She is courageous, adventurous, and a risk taker.

loans.use: buying shoes to resell

loans.name: Rosalina

texts.en:
Rosalina S., 46, is making sure that her family has enough for their daily needs. Married to Julio S., a company employee, she is blessed with two children. She makes sure that she helps her husband earn their living so that their family can have a better life.  She has been managing her small piggery for several years.

Rosalina has been a regular member of Center for Community Transformation* (CCT) for more than two years now. She regularly attends their weekly fellowship meetings and pays her weekly dues consistently. Because of her good repayment performance with her previous loans, she has been able to borrow seven times through CCT’s Cooperative.  She is consistent in paying her dues because she uses the money she borrows as added working capital for her business.    

Now with your help, Rosalina would like to apply for a PHP 16,000 loan. This amount will be used as a source of added working capital to her expanding business by buying feeds for her pigs.

She dreams that her business will grow so that they can have a better life in the future. 

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: buying feed for her pigs

loans.name: Josephine

texts.en: Josephine is a 31-year-old married mother of two children who attend school.  She has been in the grocery business selling tomatoes, potatoes and onions among other groceries for three years.  She previously owned a retail shop.  She has previously taken out three loans from Faulu Kenya and she plans to take another loan of Kes. 20,000 to add stocks of tomatoes, potatoes and onions to her business.  She dreams of owning a plot of land and building her own house in future.  She describes herself as hard-working.

loans.use: Add to her inventory

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Bolatito

texts.en:
Sarongs are worn in Nigeria by women and young ladies on special occasions.  Bolatito sells sarongs, bags, and shoes. She also sells coolers. She hopes to own an African boutique in the future and she hopes to sell only Nigerian fabrics. She loves this business because of the one-on-one interaction that she has with her customers. 

Bolatito hopes for 80,000 Nigerian naira to purchase more sarongs to sell. She is 41 years old and married with 4 children. Her eldest child is 13 years old while the youngest child is 3 years old. Her children attend school and this makes her happy. She hopes that they will become graduates in the future. Her husband also works to support their home. She thanks all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more sarongs to sell

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary is a 31-year-old married mother of two, aged seven and one year. The seven-year-old attends school. Mary's husband is a carpenter.

Mary sells shoes and charcoal, a business she has been running for the last three years. Previously, she was selling clothes to earn a living. She has requested Kes 20,000 to add to her stock of shoes and charcoal.

Mary dreams of owning a boutique in future. She describes herself as hardworking.

loans.use: To add to her stock of shoes and charcoal

loans.name: Ganhulug

texts.en:
Ganhulug is 26 years old. He and his wife and their three children live in an apartment of their own in Arhangai province, Mongolia. Ganhulug's wife helps him run his business.

In 1994-1996, Ganhulug attended a training course on the manufacture of wooden products. After he finished the training, he worked in his brother-in-law's carpentry shop but, since 2000, he has worked independently and has been operating his own carpentry business.

Originally Ganhulug had a working capital of 100,000 tugrugs (approximately 70 USD), but after a lot of hard work his working capital currently exceeds 1,290,000 tugrugs (approximately 900 USD). He usually sells his wooden furniture in Umnogovi province, Mongolia, which is approximately 650 km from his own home province.

Ganhulug is a very open and hardworking person. He says, “I would like to create my own workshop and to purchase a new truck with my business profits in order to decrease the expense of transportation.” He is requesting a 1,000,000 tugrug loan to purchase a large amount of material needed to manufacture wooden products for his customers.

loans.use: To purchase a large amount of material needed to manufacture wooden products

loans.name: Elizabeth Hurun

texts.en:
Elizabeth is a 57-year-old lady who resides in Kisumu Ndogo, Malindi and is married to Hurun with whom she has three children: James and M..

Elizabeth sells charcoal to residents and hotels within Malindi town and this she has been doing for the last twenty-four years. She normally earns a monthly profit of Ksh 12,000.

Elizabeth was introduced to KADET by an existing client and she has applied for a loan which she will use to add charcoal stock and also to repair her store. She plans to purchase a tuk tuk (a motorcycle pulling a passenger trailer) with the extra income she will earn from this loan.

A hardworking woman, Elizabeth dreams of owning a big house.

loans.use: To repair her store with Ksh 25,000 and to buy sacks of charcoal with Ksh 50,000

loans.name: Hamayil

texts.en:
Hamayil A. was born in 1951. She is married and has ten children. Agayev's family live in Fuzuli region.

A. has been in her business for eight years. Now she needs a loan of 2,000 AZN to buy turkeys, geese, and hens to improve her business.

loans.use: To buy turkeys, geese, and hens

loans.name: Jamans

texts.en:
Jamans O. is a LAPO (Lift Above Poverty Organization) client. LAPO is committed to improving lives in Nigeria and elsewhere in Africa.

Jamans sells tires at retail prices to his customers. He loves this business because it is highly profitable. He is a hardworking man and he is so determined to lift his business and family above poverty. He hopes for a loan of NGN 170,000 to purchase more tires to sell. He hopes to expand his business.

Jamans is 42 years old and married with two children, his eldest child being 6 years old. His children attend school and this gives him joy. He says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more tires to sell

loans.name: Naom

texts.en:
Naom M. N. is twenty-eight years old. She is married to a businessman and they have two children aged eight years and six years to whom they hope to give a quality education.

Naom’s business is located at Embakasi, an established and growing business area in Nairobi. Despite the fact that her business is located in Embakasi,she is served by Kitengela branch. SMEP's clients who have businesses in Embakasi are served from this branch. She has been selling tomatoes, cabbages, carrots and kale to the hotel operators and the local residents for the last seven years. She says that this business is good but at times the income she gets is not enough to take care of all her needs.

Naom is using her loan of Kes 40,000 to buy potatoes and carrots to expand her business. She hopes to become a wholesale business in future. She is very jovial and respectful.

loans.use: To buy carrots and potatoes for her business

loans.name: Joseph

texts.en:
Joseph is a 34-year-old married man with two children in school.  In the last five years, he has employed one person and sells charcoal to his area residents.  He was previously supplying bread before he ventured into the charcoal business.  

Joseph is a very hard-working man because he also earns extra income from employment.  He has been an active member of Faulu Kenya since he has been saving his money with the MFI and has previously taken out three loans.  He plans to add stocks of charcoal, and it is for this reason he requested Kes. 20,000.  He hopes to grow his business and be able to own a piece of land in the future.

loans.use: Add to his inventory
